item.title: JEnzyme
item.description: JEnzyme is a free, open-source, pure-Java library for working with EnzymeML. It helps to read and write EnzymeML documents. STRENDA Guidelines The STRENDA Guidelines are available on….

item.title: Specifications
item.description: The EnzymeML specifications define the syntax and semantics of EnzymeML. These documents are the definitive references for EnzymeML. STRENDA Guidelines The STRENDA Guidelines are available on….

item.title: Neil Swainston
item.description: Senior Research Associate at the Institute of Integrative Biology in the University of Liverpool, UK.

item.title: For experimentalists
item.description: How can EnzymeML help you to manage your experimental data? Read about use a case study in biocatalysis and enzymology. Editing of EnzymeML: simulation of time course data from kinetic parameters We artificially created a time course data using entry KJWIQY from the STRENDA DB. The time course was simulated at different initial concentrations in the range of 25.0 to 500.0 Î¼M as noted in the STRENDA DB entry. It should be noted that each different concentration was created as a duplicate species entry with varying initial concentration and identified by a suffix in the name (e.

item.title: PyEnzyme
item.description: JEnzyme is a free, open-source, Python library for working with EnzymeML. It helps to read and write EnzymeML documents. Original Peer Review Papers Paper 1 Paper 2

item.title: Use cases
item.description: Here you will find details of selected case studies applying EnzymeML for experimentalists, modelers and software developers Original Peer Review Papers Paper 1 Paper 2

item.title: Frank T. Bergmann
item.description: Postdoctoral researcher at the Modeling of Biological Processes Group in Centre for Organismal Studies at the Heidelberg University, Germany.

item.title: For modelers
item.description: Looking for software and databases that read and write EnzymeML? Here we present you one example to inspire your team. Kinetic modeling of EnzymeML data with COPASI You can analyze and model time course enzyme kinetic data stored in EnzymeML with the biochemical systems simulator COPASI. The integration can be done using the PyEnzyme library and a COPASI-specific thin API layer (TL_COPASI). Once you are in COPASI, you can employ different kinetic laws to estimate kinetic parameters and test reaction mechanisms, and plot your results.

item.title: Publications
item.description: This section lists published papers and chapters describing EnzymeML and core EnzymeML-supporting software tools. Original Peer Review Papers Paper 1 Paper 2

item.title: Specific APIs
item.description: A free, open-source API library for working with EnzymeML content. It presently supports COPASI, SABIO-RK and STRENDA DB. Original Peer Review Papers Paper 1 Paper 2

item.title: Santiago Schnell
item.description: Interim Chair of Department of Molecular & Integrative Physiology at the University of Michigan Medical School, USA.

item.title: For Software Developers
item.description: Want to implement EnzymeML read and write functionalities in your software or database? Here we present you one example to inspire your team. Uploading EnzymeML documents to SABIO-RK SABIO-RK is a curated database that contains information about biochemical reactions, their kinetic rate equations with parameters, and experimental conditions. YOu can use an EnzymeML parsers, JEnzyme or PyEnzyme, to read in EnzymeML documents and to create a new SABIO-RK entry. Once the entry is created, SABIO-RK curators check the created entry before it is posted to the public SABIO-RK database.

item.title: Software and Databases Guide
item.description: The EnzymeML Software and Database Guide provides a summary of all EnzymeMLBML-compatible software systems and databases currently available. Original Peer Review Papers Paper 1 Paper 2

item.title: Validators
item.description: A portable, low-level, tools for annocating and validating EnzymeML files.

item.title: Contact
item.description: EnzymeML Project Contacts The primary project contact is JÃ¼rgen Pleiss. You can also send your questions to Neil Swainston, or Santiago Schnell, who are also contact project coordinators. STRENDA Guidelines If you are interested to learn more about the STRENDA Guidelines, please contact Carsten Kettner. Website Santiago Schnell is the primary contact for the website updates.
